verses.text: But Solomon took thirteen years to finish building his own house.
verses.comment: The time taken is emphasized, contrasting with the temple construction (see 1 Kgs 6:38).

verses.text: He built the House of the Forest of Lebanon; it was 150 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high, on four rows of cedar pillars, with cedar beams on the pillars.
verses.comment: Measurements are converted to feet for modern readers; the building resembles a grand palace.

verses.text: It was covered with cedar above the chambers that rested on the pillars, forty-five chambers, fifteen in a row.
verses.comment: Describes cedar roof and arrangement of rooms.

verses.text: There were windows in three rows, and facing window was opposite window in three rows.
verses.comment: Depicts symmetry and abundance of windows.

verses.text: All the doorways and windows had square frames, and window was opposite window in three rows.
verses.comment: Reinforces the previous verse’s architectural symmetry.

verses.text: He made the Hall of Pillars: it was 75 feet long and 45 feet wide. There was a porch in front, and pillars with a canopy before them.
verses.comment: Hall dimensions and the porch are clarified.

verses.text: He made the Hall of the Throne where he was to judge, that is, the Hall of Judgment; it was covered with cedar from the floor to the ceiling.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Solomon’s role as king and judge.

verses.text: His own house, where he would live, in the other court behind the hall, was similar in workmanship. Solomon also made a house for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had taken as his wife, like this hall.
verses.comment: References Solomon’s Egyptian wife and her own palace.

verses.text: All these were made of costly stones, cut according to measure, sawed with saws, inside and out, from the foundation to the top, and from the outside to the great court.
verses.comment: Describes the skilled workmanship and quality materials.

verses.text: The foundation was of costly great stones, some ten cubits, some eight cubits long.
verses.comment: Stones of varying and massive size; one cubit ≈ 1.5 feet.

verses.text: And above were costly stones, cut to size, and cedar wood.
verses.comment: Continues the description of luxurious materials.

verses.text: The great court had three courses of cut stone all around, and a course of cedar beams, like the inner court of the house of the Lord and the vestibule of the house.
verses.comment: Parallels the construction style of the temple.

verses.text: King Solomon sent and brought Hiram from Tyre.
verses.comment: Hiram was a renowned craftsman from Phoenicia (modern Lebanon).

verses.text: He was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre, a bronze worker. He was filled with wisdom, understanding, and skill in working with bronze. He came to King Solomon and did all his work.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Hiram’s mixed Israelite and Tyrian lineage.

verses.text: He cast two pillars of bronze, each 27 feet high and 18 feet in circumference.
verses.comment: Heights are modernized (18 cubits ≈ 27 feet; circumference from 12 cubits ≈ 18 feet).

verses.text: He made two capitals of cast bronze to set on top of the pillars; the height of one capital was 7.5 feet, and the other capital was also 7.5 feet high.
verses.comment: One capital’s height is 5 cubits (≈ 7.5 feet).

verses.text: He made latticework of interwoven chains for the capitals on top of the pillars, seven chains for one capital and seven for the other.
verses.comment: Describes decorative elements atop the pillars.

verses.text: He made pomegranates; two rows around each latticework to cover the capitals on top of the pillars. He did the same for both capitals.
verses.comment: Pomegranate decorations symbolize abundance/fertility.

verses.text: The capitals on top of the pillars in the portico were shaped like lilies, four and a half feet high.
verses.comment: ‘Four cubits high’ rendered as ≈ 6 feet; value rounded for clarity.

verses.text: The capitals on the two pillars also had rows of pomegranates above the round part next to the latticework—there were 200 pomegranates in rows all around each capital.
verses.comment: Count of pomegranates as per original text.

verses.text: He set up the pillars at the front of the temple. He set up the right pillar and called it Jachin, and he set up the left pillar and called it Boaz.
verses.comment: Names are retained from Hebrew with their traditional spellings.

verses.text: On top of the pillars was work shaped like lilies. So the construction of the pillars was finished.
verses.comment: Summarizes the completion of the decorative work.

verses.text: Then he made the Sea of cast metal, circular in shape, 15 feet from rim to rim, 7.5 feet high, and 45 feet in circumference.
verses.comment: ‘Sea’ refers to a large basin for ritual washing; dimensions modernized.

verses.text: Under its rim were gourds, encircling it, ten per cubit, all around the Sea. The gourds were cast in two rows when the Sea was cast.
verses.comment: Ten per cubit interpreted as dense, decorative pattern.

verses.text: It stood on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east. The Sea was set on top of them, and all their hindquarters faced inward.
verses.comment: Positioning of the oxen clarity added.

verses.text: Its thickness was three inches, and its rim was shaped like the rim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It held about 11,000 gallons.
verses.comment: ‘A handbreadth thick’ rendered as 3 inches; ‘2,000 baths’ as ≈ 11,000 gallons (about 44,000 liters).

verses.text: He also made ten bronze stands, each was 6 feet long, 6 feet wide, and 4.5 feet high.
verses.comment: Measurements converted from cubits.

verses.text: This was how the stands were made: they had panels, and the panels were set in frames.
verses.comment: Describes the arrangement of the panels for clarity.

verses.text: On the panels between the frames were lions, oxen, and cherubim. On the frames above and below the lions and oxen were wreaths of hammered work.
verses.comment: Describes the ornate bronze decorations.

verses.text: Each stand had four bronze wheels with bronze axles. At the four corners were supports for a basin, cast with wreaths at each side.
verses.comment: Wheels and axles for mobility; supports for wash basins explained.

verses.text: At the top of the stand there was a circular opening one and a half feet deep; the opening was round, made as a stand, about two and a quarter feet in diameter. At the opening were engravings, but the panels were square, not round.
verses.comment: Dimensions clarified; opening for the basin and decorative engravings.

verses.text: The four wheels were under the panels; the axles of the wheels were attached to the stand. Each wheel was two and a quarter feet high.
verses.comment: Wheel height converted from cubits for modern readers.

verses.text: The wheels were made like chariot wheels; their axles, rims, spokes, and hubs were all cast.
verses.comment: Comparison to chariot wheels for familiarity and durability.

verses.text: There were supports at the four corners of each stand; the supports were of one piece with the stand itself.
verses.comment: Explains the method to ensure structural strength.

verses.text: At the top of the stand there was a rounded band nine inches high, and the supports and panels were cast as one piece with it.
verses.comment: ‘Half a cubit’ rendered as 9 inches.

verses.text: On the flat surfaces of the supports and on the panels, he engraved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, wherever there was space, with wreaths all around.
verses.comment: Explains detailed ornamental engravings.

verses.text: He made the ten stands all the same: the same casting, measurements, and shape.
verses.comment: Confirms uniformity of the stands.

verses.text: Then he made ten bronze basins, each holding about 220 gallons and measuring six feet across, one basin for each of the ten stands.
verses.comment: Measurements and capacity modernized (forty baths ≈ 220 gallons).

verses.text: He set the stands: five on the south side of the house and five on the north side. The Sea he set at the southeast corner of the house.
verses.comment: Orientation of the stands and Sea specified.

verses.text: Hiram also made the pots, shovels, and bowls. So Hiram finished all the work that he did for King Solomon on the house of the Lord:
verses.comment: Concludes the list of Hiram’s bronze work for the temple.

verses.text: the two pillars, the two bowls of the capitals on top of the pillars, the two latticeworks to cover the two bowls of the capitals on top of the pillars,
verses.comment: List restates major bronze items.

verses.text: the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks (two rows of pomegranates for each latticework, to cover the two bowls of the capitals on the pillars),
verses.comment: Totals four hundred pomegranates, 200 per pillar.

verses.text: the ten stands and the ten basins on the stands,
verses.comment: Restates what was previously described in detail.

verses.text: the one Sea, and the twelve oxen under the Sea,
verses.comment: Lists Sea and the support oxen.

verses.text: and the pots, shovels, and bowls. All these vessels, which Hiram made for King Solomon for the house of the Lord, were of polished bronze.
verses.comment: Note on the material and finish (polished or burnished bronze).

verses.text: The king cast them in clay molds in the plain of the Jordan, between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.comment: Casting location is specified.

verses.text: Solomon left all the vessels unweighed, because there were so many; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
verses.comment: Bronze was used in such quantity that it wasn't weighed.

verses.text: So Solomon made all the vessels that were in the house of the Lord: the golden altar, the golden table for the bread of the Presence,
verses.comment: Now describes the gold furnishings.

verses.text: the lampstands of pure gold, five on the south side and five on the north, before the inner sanctuary; with the flowers, lamps, and tongs, of gold;
verses.comment: Focuses on interior temple furnishings.

verses.text: the cups, snuffers, bowls, dishes, and fire pans, of pure gold; the sockets for the doors of the inner sanctuary, the Most Holy Place, and for the doors of the nave of the temple, were of gold.
verses.comment: Lists all gold utensils and even door fittings.

verses.text: So all the work that King Solomon did on the house of the Lord was finished. Solomon brought in the things which David his father had dedicated: the silver, the gold, and the vessels, and put them in the treasuries of the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Concludes with the transfer of dedicated items to the temple treasury.
